metadata.title: Dysphagia  Oromandibular Dystonia
anatomical location body part affected: Mouth, oropharynx, pharynx, central nervous system(1,2)
description: Dystonia refers to the presence of sustained muscle spasms that usually produce twisting, repetitive movements or abnormal postures.(2) Oromandibular dystonia (OMD) is associated with abnormal repetitive movements of the muscles that move the mouth, face, jaw, and tongue that can lead to problems with chewing and swallowing.(3) The following symptoms have been reported in patients with OMD: bruxism (excessive teeth grinding or jaw clenching), muscle pain, involuntary movements of the tongue, pain during chewing, lip pursing, biting of tongue, and involuntary muscle contractions of the masseter (jaw muscle)(1,3,30,33)

ICD-10 codes.G24.4: idiopathic orofacial dystonia; oromandibular dystonia _ (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

presentation signs and symptoms: Dysphagia refers to an inability to move food or liquid efficiently during the oral, pharyngeal, or esophageal phase of swallowing.(4) The oral phase includes sucking, chewing, and moving the food or liquid into the throat. The pharyngeal phase is the initiation of the swallowing reflex, when the food or liquid is squeezed down the throat and the airway is closed off to prevent aspiration (food or liquid entering the airway) or choking. In the esophageal phase, the openings at the top and bottom of the esophagus move the food or liquid to the stomach by relaxing and tightening.(5)In patients with OMD, the oral phase is usually affected to a greater degree than the pharyngeal phase.(34)Symptoms of dysphagia in patients with OMD primarily are difficulty chewing and preparing the bolus for efficient swallowing(1) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Review all medical records prior to conducting an examination

During a swallowing evaluation, it is of utmost importance to be aware of a patient’s pain level, fatigue level, and frustration level. The time of day and the number of previous evaluations can affect the patient’s alertness and performance. Swallowing assessments should be scheduled at a time of day when the patient is less fatigued and should not occur following other assessments
It is recommended that the caregiver/family be involved in all assessment procedures

pathogenesis: Pathogenesis varies with the origin of OMD. Not all patients with OMD experience chewing and swallowing difficulties.Investigators in a study conducted in the United States involving 32 patients with OMD reported that 15.6% of the patientsexperienced symptoms of eating dysfunction due to symptoms of OMD(3)
risk factors for omd: Oromandibular trauma associated with a dental procedure or facial injury(1)

overall contraindications precautions: Speech-language  pathologists (SLPs) are required to have graduate, postgraduate, or continuing education training specifically in dysphagia assessment and treatment(6)
To perform videofluoroscopic swallowing studies (VFSS), an SLP must have established competencies in the use and storage of barium used in VFSSs(7)

Patients with dysphagia are at risk for aspiration and/or penetration of oral intake. Ensure that the patient and family/ caregivers are aware of potential aspiration risks and educated about prevention strategies when appropriate
The patient’s family/caregivers should be involved in assessment and treatment procedures
A patient’s culture and native language should be considered to determine the appropriateness of examination questions and materials
It is important to consider eating habits, food preferences, dietary restrictions,and cultural influences on eating to maximize nutritional intake

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document the onset of the OMD and any recent history of dental procedures or facial surgery(1)

course of treatment.medical management: Symptoms of OMD have been found to be ameliorated by oral medication such as anticholinergics, which block the action of acetylcholine on the muscle receptors (e.g., trihexyphenidyl), and by injections of botulinum toxin type A (BTXA).(3,8,9,30,32) Possible side effects of BTX-A injections include jaw  weakness, loss of a smile, dysphagia, nasal regurgitation, and jaw tremor.(1,10) Side effects can be decreased with dose adjustments(1)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Ask a pharmacist or physician about the side effects of these medications. The following medications have been Antidystonic medications such as trihexyphenidyl, lorazepam, and tetrabenazine(3)BTX-A  is often injected into the affected muscles to manage symptoms(3)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Diagnosis of OMD is made by a physician based upon clinical symptoms.(9) Instrumental investigations are required to rule out organic causes or other disorders. For example, the patient might undergo MRI to rule out a stroke or lesion in the basal ganglia(1)
Usual tests for dysphagia include the following:
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies and whether they help. Patients with OMD sometimes develop sensory “tricks” to ameliorate their symptoms (e.g., chewing gum, yelling, holding a pen between the lips)(3)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational, physical, or speech therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Does the patient have any pain while chewing? Does the patient have blepharospasms (spasms that cause forcible closure of the eyelids)?(3,31) Does the patient wear dentures? Does the patient exhibit wear or loss of teeth?(1) Are the symptoms exacerbated by fatigue or stress? Does the patient exhibit increased swallowing -with certain textures of foods or liquids? -in different environments? -as meals progress? -during certain times of day? -if fatigued? -with environmental distractions?
history of present illness.body chart: Review body chart to determine whether the dystonia is limited to the oral musculature
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: The effects of OMD on swallowing and chewing can range from none to severe and include social embarrassment and weight loss.(3) Pharyngeal dystonia has been reported as a possible symptom of OMD, but it is more(1) -Involuntary movements of the jaw (e.g., jaw opening, spasms that cause jaw closure, teeth clenching) that interfere with chewing(3) -Involuntary movements of the tongue (e.g., tongue thrusting, sweeping movements of the tongue) that lead to poor bolus preparation and control(1,3) -Pain during chewing(3) -Lip pursing(3) -Biting of tongue(1)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); document any history of coughing while eating. Document any fatigue while eating
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., weight loss, coughing, chest congestion, difficulty with oral hygiene, weakness, constipation, urine retention, speech disturbances, anxiety)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document any history of respiratory difficulties OMD can cause embarrassment during eating and interfere with a patient’s ability to socialize while eating.(3) Facial distortions caused by OMD might also cause cosmetic embarrassment(1)An outcome measure that includes patient self-ratings  of quality of life due to swallowing and eating ability(12)Document hearing ability, including hearing impairment and use of hearing aids or cochlear implants Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document any previous history of swallowing difficulties, respiratory difficulties, or communication difficulties
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Refer to medical charts and ask patient or patient’s family about other problems, including depression, hearing loss, vision problems, heart problems, communication difficulties (including dysarthria), and memory loss
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing (e.g., spillage of food or liquids from the oral cavity, excessive throat clearing, coughing while eating)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in regular work or hobbies? Does the patient’s OMD interfere with his or her ability to participate in vocational or leisure activities?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document if the patient uses any adaptive equipment to communicate (e.g., pen/paper, communication board). Does the patient feed self? Is the patient limited to eating foods of only certain textures?
social and occupational history.living environment: Document with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient use any adaptive devices for mobility, communication, or eating (e.g., adaptive spoons, cups)?
observation inspection palpation includi: Other instrumental procedures include ultrasonography to observe movement of the structures used for swallowing and surface electromyography to record the electrical activity of the swallowing muscles; however, these procedures are used primarily in research at this time.(6) Bronchial auscultation by a physical therapist has also been used as an adjunct to a CSE(26)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Note any posture abnormalities that might interfere with swallowing (e.g., head tilt, unilateral weakness)Document if the patient is able to eat independently and/or prepare his or her own food
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Vision and hearing screening should be performed to determine any barriers to communication and ability to follow treatment protocol. Ideally, referral to an audiologist to check for impacted cerumen should be made prior to hearing screening. If the patient has hearing aids or cochlear implants, they should be checked to be sure they are in working order
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisa 25-item questionnaire that assesses the impact of OMD on a person’s general health, psychosocial well-being,  appearance, speech, and eating ability(34)
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: It is important to screen receptive language before a swallow evaluation to determine the patient’s ability to follow directions. Patients with OMD might have speech/articulation abnormalities that result from deviant movements of the lips, tongue, and jaw.(3) Common characteristics of dysarthria in patients with OMD include  reduced precision in articulation of both consonants and vowels as well as reduced fluency of speech.(34) For detailed information on assessment of aphasia and dysarthria, see the series of Clinical Reviews on these topics
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Refer to psychological testing for information on attention and cognition
relevant tests and measures.swallow examination: The purpose of a swallow examination is to determine if the patient has dysphagia, to determine which function is disordered, and to establish any compensatory strategies (change in swallowing manner or food consistency) that would be safe and beneficial to the patient(6)A CSE is usually the first part of a comprehensive swallowing examination or is used as an initial screening to determine the need for further evaluation.(6)Historically, the lack of a gag reflex function was used as a measure of dysphagia, but this has been demonstrated as unreliable as the sole indicator of dysphagia. The features associated witha wet voice, weak voluntary cough, cough on swallowing, and delayed or prolonged swallow.(13) However, a CSE is unable to detect silent aspiration (aspiration of food or liquid into the lungs without overt signs) and cannot be used to determine the physiologic reason for a cough or a voice quality change. Due to its limitations, a CSE should be used as a complement to other instrumental measures rather than in isolation.(13) If oral intake is considered relatively safe, the patient might be observed swallowing different consistencies of food during the CSE.(11) Cervical auscultation (the use of a stethoscope to assess swallow sounds and airway sounds) and pulse oximetry (oxygen saturation is measured before, during, and after swallowing; decreased saturation during and after swallowing is reported to be associated with aspiration) can be used during trial swallows to better detect penetration/aspiration atCervicalT709101 and Clinical Review…Dysphagia AssessmentT709100. For adults, the CSE might include the following -A comprehensive case history and review of medical records(6) -Assessment of oral structures and motor function. Note the appearance of the oral mucosa (e.g., any inflammation or infection that might affect the oral stage of swallowing) and any pooling of saliva in the oral cavity. An inability to swallow might cause the saliva to pool in the mouth. Evaluate dentition in terms of the presence or absence of dental prostheses, the number and appearance of teeth, and general dental care.(6) Examine the facial, labial, and lingual ROM, speed, and strength. Examine velar elevation -Assessment of speech and vocal quality(6) -Assessment of feeding and mealtime techniques used by patient and caregivers.(6) When possible, conduct the CSE during a typical meal to observe the patient’s skills in coordinating respiration and swallowing in a natural environment.(6) Assess patient’s ability to achieve labial seal and contain bolus. Examine retrieval of different food consistencies from a spoon, cup, and straw -Assessment of the pharyngeal phase using palpation. To assess tongue base function, hyoid motion, and laryngeal motion during a swallow, place one finger under the patient’s chin at the base of the tongue, the next finger on the hyoid bone, the next finger above the larynx, and the next finger below the larynx.(15) As the patient swallows, examine for the presence and extent of laryngeal elevation -Observation of the effects of alterations in posture or other compensatory techniques to improve swallow(6) -Evaluation of the patient’s ability to comprehend instructions and use compensatory strategies(16)In-depth  Bedside SwallowT709064and Clinical Review…Dysphagia AssessmentT709037Several screening protocols have been published to assist the clinician during the CSE -Burke Dysphagia Screening Test (BDST) -Standardized Swallowing Assessment (SSA) -Bedside Swallowing Assessment (BSA) –Assessment scales/checklistsLip, cheek, tongue, and jaw movement are rated during a typical meal. This scale can be used with patients from 1 year of age through adulthood(18)A statistically based protocol for patients who are dependent feeders. Scaled ratings are made for posture, tone, reflexes, general motor control, orofacial structures, orofacial sensory input, orofacial motor control, ventilation, and functional feeding assessment(19) Ratings of lip, jaw, and tongue movement during ingestion of liquids and solid foods. Assessment of sipping from a cup, coughing, gagging, and hypersensitivity associated with feeding and swallowing. A checklist allows for indication of abnormal oral structures, oral reflexes, positioning, diet, utensils, and feeding(20)Standardized screening survey that can be used with children from 2 years of age through adulthood. Assesses BMI, restrictions in food textures and viscosity, dependence in feeding, and need for special utensils or positioning. Provides information on the severity of the swallowing disorder and can be used as an outcome measure(21)VFSS is performed in collaboration with a physician (radiologist or physiatrist) and an SLP or occupational therapist and is used primarily as a diagnostic procedure for dysphagia.(6) Most clinical practices follow the protocol originally described by Logemann.(22) The patient eats and drinks a variety of liquids and solids mixed with barium while images are recorded with videofluorography. All patients should be examined in the lateral and frontal positions to gain information on movements of the swallow and symmetry of bolus flow and pharyngeal wall contraction. The SLP examines for the presence of aspiration and the effectiveness of modifying different food consistencies or of modifying posture.(6) In contrast to the CSE, a VFSS provides critical information on the pharyngeal and esophageal phases of the swallow.(11) Due to the levels of radiation involved, this procedure is not suitable to use frequently to monitor changes.(13) Given the unnatural surroundings, swallowing function observed during a VFSS is not necessarily identical to swallowing function evident at mealtimes.(17) Other variables that might influence swallowing function include anxiety, fatigue, and medications.(23) During the VFSS,(16,23) -Lip closure (ability to contain a liquid bolus) -Lingual elevation (the back of the tongue is slightly elevated) -Tongue-to-palatal  seal -Bolus preparation/mastication -Bolus transport/movement of the tongue (movement of the bolus to the back of the oral cavity) -Initiation of the pharyngeal swallow (swallow should be initiated when the bolus reaches the region of the posterior oral cavity) -Soft palate elevation and retraction -Laryngeal elevation -Anterior hyoid excursion -Laryngeal closure -Pharyngeal contraction -Pharyngoesophageal segment opening -Tongue base retraction -Epiglottic inversion -Esophageal clearanceModified Barium SwallowT709077and Clinical Review…Dysphagia AssessmentT709046FEES is performed to evaluate the anatomy and physiology of the pharynx and the larynx, pharyngeal swallow function, and the patient’s ability to manage secretions as well as ability to swallow foods and liquids.(6) In addition, it can be used to explore a variety of diagnostic interventions such as varying bolus consistency, varying posture, and making use of visual feedback for reinforcement.(24) After the insertion of the endoscope, the patient can self-feed during the evaluation. Food must be light in color to enhance visibility (e.g., milk, puddings, yogurt, bread). FEES is preferred over VFSS when patients have safety issues related to radiation exposure or when they need frequent retesting. In addition, FEES might be less taxing than VFSS for patients who are weak and bedridden.(24) The American Speech-Language-Hearing  Association (ASHA) has published several online documents relevant to the technical aspects of FEES and the qualifications required to perform FEES(25) -For detailed information on FEES and endoscopic examinations for dysphagia, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia
relevant tests and measures.tracheostomy examination: If present, assess tracheostomy tube and document date of placement, current respiratory status, and use of speaking valve. other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with dysphagia are at risk for aspiration and penetration of oral intake. Ensure that the patient and family/ caregivers are aware of potential aspiration risks and are educated about prevention strategies when appropriate
It is important to consider eating habits, food preferences, dietary restrictions, and cultural influences on eating to maximize nutritional intake

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Dysphagia diagnosis and management is based upon the results of a comprehensive assessment that is performed by an SLP in collaboration with a transdisciplinary team that might include a dietician, occupational therapist, physical therapist, respiratory therapist, otolaryngologist, radiologist, social worker, and neurologist.(27) Each discipline provides specific input and expertise on the patient’s swallowing problems and the treatment plan. The primary concern is to maintain and maximize the patient’s health status.(6) After the evaluation, a decision must be made about the patient’s ability to ingest food and water orally based upon the nature of the disorder and his or her ability to make adjustments
assessment plan of care.rule out: The physician must identify the root cause of the OMD (e.g., trauma, drug-induced  [tardive], Wilson’s disease). Dental problems, temporomandibular joint syndrome, and psychological disturbance must be ruled out(10)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer to an occupational therapist, physical therapist, nutritionist, respiratory therapist, social worker, neurologist, otolaryngologist, or radiologist as necessary
treatment summary: Diet modification:  Changing the food and/or liquid consistency of a patient’s diet might assist in improving the safety and efficiency of the oral stage and pharyngeal stages of the swallow as well as reducing any pain associated with eating.(3) If the patient experiences aspiration of liquids or difficulty containing the liquid in the oral cavity, the clinician can investigate the use of thickened liquids; however, it cannot be assumed that all patients will benefit from thickened liquids.(28) Clinicians should explore all possible intervention options before recommending thickened liquids, and also determine (by observing modifications during VFSS or FEES), rather than assume, that aspiration is not occurring with thickened liquids(29)  –For detailed information about using thickened liquids for patients with dysphagia, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Swallowing Therapy –Compensatory ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709081

Adaptive equipment:  Adaptive spoons, cups, and straws might be used to assist with the oral stage of the swallow. For example, if the patient has difficulty achieving a labial seal and cannot drink from a straw, a nonspill cup with a large handle might be useful as a facilitative aid. If anterior leakage continues, spoons can be used to place the liquid more posterior in the mouth(15) . increased swallowing safety reduced aspi: Presence of aspiration (measured by presence of fevers, X-rays)(15)
improved nutrition and hydration: Measures of liquid intake and skin turgor(15)

maintenance or prevention: Management of dysphagia in patients with OMD involves regular monitoring of the swallow and adapting goals and strategies as necessary
patient education: The SLP is responsible for educating the family and patient-care  staff about the needs of the patient regarding swallow safety
